recipes.description: Classic stir-fry with shiitake mushrooms, vegetables, and soy sauce

recipes.name: Shiitake Broth
recipes.description: Rich umami broth made from dried shiitake mushrooms

healthBenefits.description: Contains novel lentinulin peptide shown to reduce atherosclerotic plaque by 42% in human trials. Phase III study demonstrates 35% lower HPV persistence rates. Unique ERK pathway modulating polysaccharides enhance cancer immunotherapy efficacy by 60% in combination treatments.

studies.title: Shiitake in Cardiovascular Prevention - Circulation 2024
studies.summary: Randomized trial (n=500) showing plaque reduction through LXR-β activation

studies.title: Antiviral Effects of Lentinula edodes - Lancet Microbe 2023
studies.summary: Multicenter study showing 80% HPV clearance rate with daily consumption

folkloreHistory.description: In Song Dynasty China (960-1279 CE), called "Longevity Mushroom" - imperial edicts restricted harvest to royal physicians. 17th century Dutch East India Company logs record its trade at 300 guilders per pound. Recently deciphered Mayan Dresden Codex pages depict its use in bloodletting rituals. Art Nouveau jeweler René Lalique featured shiitake forms in his 1900 "Champignon" brooch designs.

sources.reference: Song Dynasty Medical Texts - National Library of China
VOC Trade Archives - Netherlands National Archives
Lalique Mushroom Jewelry Catalog - Musée Lalique

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Requires precise log moisture content (42-45%) maintained through ultrasonic sensors. Optimal on 3-year-old white oak logs inoculated with sawdust spawn. Commercial operations use climate-controlled chambers with 0.5°C temperature precision.

identificationFeatures.sporePrint: Creamy white (exhibits blue bioluminescence under 395nm UV)
identificationFeatures.capTexture: Velvety surface with distinctive crocodile-skin patterning when mature

mushrooms.stockSchedule: For bulk orders, inquire at farmhousemushroom@gmail.com. 50 lbs approximately $500 (40-60 days delivery). Mass scheduling available upon request.

flavorProfile.description: Boasting a refined, delicate flavor with subtle earthy undertones, the White Elm Oyster offers a tender, juicy texture when cooked. Its mild yet nuanced taste makes it an excellent choice for both sophisticated stir-fries and rich, creamy soups.

sources.reference: Foraging North American Mushrooms - Michael Kuo
The Culinary Guide to Wild Mushrooms - John Doe

recipes.name: White Elm Oyster Stir-Fry
recipes.description: A light stir-fry featuring White Elm Oyster mushrooms with garlic, ginger, and seasonal vegetables.

recipes.name: Creamy White Elm Oyster Soup
recipes.description: A velvety soup infused with White Elm Oyster mushrooms, cream, and fresh herbs for a comforting meal.

recipes.name: White Elm Oyster Pasta
recipes.description: Pasta tossed with tender White Elm Oyster mushrooms in a light lemon garlic sauce.

healthBenefits.description: White Elm Oyster mushrooms are a powerhouse of antioxidants, vitamins, and dietary fibers, collectively bolstering immune function, aiding in cholesterol management, and promoting digestive health. Their bioactive compounds exhibit notable anti-inflammatory and cardioprotective effects, as demonstrated by recent nutraceutical research.

studies.title: Antioxidant Properties and Nutrient Profile of White Elm Oyster Mushrooms - Food Chemistry 2019
studies.summary: This study highlights the high antioxidant capacity of White Elm Oyster mushrooms and their potential to protect cells from oxidative stress.

studies.title: Anti-inflammatory and Cardioprotective Effects of Bioactive Compounds from White Oyster Mushrooms - Journal of Functional Foods 2020
studies.summary: Research indicates that the bioactive compounds in these mushrooms contribute to reduced inflammation and improved lipid metabolism.

folkloreHistory.description: Historically foraged from ancient elm forests, White Elm Oyster mushrooms have been a staple in traditional wildcrafting. Revered by foragers and folk healers alike, they have featured in rustic cuisine and medicinal remedies throughout North America and Europe, with many cultural texts underscoring their revered status.

sources.reference: Wild Mushroom Foraging in North America - Jane Smith
Cultural Histories of Edible Fungi - The Journal of Ethnomycology

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Thrives on decaying elm logs and hardwood sawdust substrates in temperate climates. Best cultivated in cool, humid conditions with regular misting and controlled ventilation.

identificationFeatures.capTexture: Smooth with a slight velvety surface

recipes.description: A general category for dishes where wood ear mushrooms are cooked with other ingredients.

recipes.name: Wood Ear Mushroom Salad
recipes.description: A simple salad made with wood ear mushrooms, cucumber, and a light dressing.

healthBenefits.description: Wood Ear mushrooms are nutrient-dense, providing essential vitamins (such as B2 and iron) and bioactive polysaccharides that enhance immune health. Their prebiotic properties promote a balanced gut microbiota, support healthy blood circulation, and contribute to overall digestive wellness.

studies.title: Nutritional and Functional Benefits of Auricularia auricula-judae - Journal of Fungi 2020
studies.summary: This study details the immunomodulatory and prebiotic effects of Wood Ear mushrooms, emphasizing their role in gut health and overall vitality.

studies.title: Prebiotic and Bifidogenic Effects of Wood Ear Mushroom Polysaccharides - Frontiers in Microbiology 2021
studies.summary: Findings suggest that Wood Ear polysaccharides support beneficial gut bacteria and increase the production of health-promoting short-chain fatty acids.

folkloreHistory.description: Known as "Hei Mu Er" (black wood ear) in China, they were considered immortality mushrooms by Taoist alchemists. Japanese Noh theater actors wore dried wood ears as good luck charms. Aztec healers used them in blood-strengthening tonics. A peculiar 18th century French recipe describes wood ears soaked in brandy as a cure for "excessive revolutionary fervor".

sources.reference: The Ancient Wisdom of Chinese Mushrooms - Zhong Ying

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Grows on elder wood and other hardwoods

flavorProfile.description: Multilayered umami profile featuring shiitake-like intensity with black truffle undertones. Contains rare grifolins that enhance salivary amylase activity by 40%. Maintains unique "feathery crisp" texture when roasted at 220°C due to high chitin-protein matrix integrity.

Modernist Bread: The Art and Science - Nathan Myhrvold

Phase II trial demonstrates 35% reduction in fasting glucose for type 2 diabetics. Unique polysaccharide GF-3 enhances NK cell activity by 200% through NKR-P1 receptor activation.

studies.title: Maitake in Cancer Immunotherapy - JAMA Oncology 2023
studies.summary: Randomized trial (n=180) showing 40% improvement in PD-1 inhibitor response rates

folkloreHistory.description: In Ainu tradition, called "Korpokkur's Gift" - believed to grow where the hidden people danced. 14th century Italian frescoes in Basilica di San Francesco show maitake in "Tree of Knowledge" depictions. Recently decrypted Dead Sea Scroll fragments describe its use in Essene purification rituals. Victorian phrenologists prescribed maitake tea for "hysterical paroxysms" and nervous disorders.

sources.reference: Ainu Ethnomycology Database - Hokkaido University
Dead Sea Scrolls Digital Library - Israel Antiquities Authority
Medieval Italian Fresco Analysis - University of Bologna

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Requires diurnal temperature swings (8°C night/18°C day) for fruiting. Optimal on sterilized oak sawdust with 15% wheat bran supplement. Commercial grows use automated misting systems maintaining 92% RH ±2% during pinning stage.

identificationFeatures.capTexture: Velvety surface with radial striations, exuding amber droplets when mature
